body.p: I duly received your parcel and am further obliged for your care of me. I have distributed the Memorial Tokens of your son's death, where I thought they would create a lasting feeling, and, among others your name and virtues are not unknown to, but are fully appreciated by, my Gloucestershire Friends. I mat at Staley BridgeStalybridge yesterday, a young Sheffield Traveller whom I so far interested as to hear him solicit a correspondence with me. I referred him to you as the best medium for that: but I neglected to ask his card. I have been three nights and am to have a fourth tomorrow at Hyde discoursing with Stephens whether we should seek the Repeal of the New Poor Law Amendment Act, in preference to going for the Tithes and other Church Property as an original and still legal right wherewith to supersede the necessity of any Poor Law. I have had nothing but his audience to address and when I pressed [[2]] him hard he knew how to relieve himself by appealing to their ignorance and their passions against me. It has however been a most interesting, most excitable and useful discussion. I had to make him angry by provocation before I could bring him out ; but we shall separate better friends. Stephens has a deal of bilious ferocity about him and but little of the amenities and suavities of civilized life: but this must be confessed, that he has ringleted and thrown away the favours of the rich to advocate a better lot for the lowest poor. Taking his character altogether, I like it ; but I see great room for improvement in it. He is not deep in knowledge ; but strong in style of expressing what he knows. He could not interest an intelligent audience; but he deeply interests his non intelligent one. I had something to do to keeping grace and favour with them after calling [[3]] him out. Still I have accomplished my purpose of reaching them.

I have some little prospect of a theological discussion with a respectable man in Manchester, arising from my going to Beard's Chapel on the wednesday evening. Otherwise my room has been ill attended since Christmas. The class of people that should come to me now stand off on account of their yet unmoved prejudices toward me on the old ground: while the devil they make me frightens others. The Radicals are here low and despicable, not worth the courting. The Owenites are the best class; but they are sectarian and fanatical, hating all professed reformers who are not Owenite. shall we ever see mankind, or will future eyes see them working together for common good? I begin to doubt it; still I would have no effort relinquished toward it, now or for ever. We may as well be going this as any thing else and better than being idle and listless: To save some, if we cannot save all, is something.

I send you a hundred of each of two Penny Tracts and 50 Three halfpenny ; wishing you to shop them with Barraclough and Lingard if you can: or do the best you can with them. If nothing else, give them away. you will find them interesting.

[[4]] I shall be very glad to come to Sheffield any week in which there is a way open to my doing any good. I should not like to come there if I could not get a public standing room for an audience: for I had rather address the Lancashire folks in the open air this summer. My Norwich opponent Green has gone mad and is really under restraint. I am going there in May. In Sheffield, hitherto, I have not failed to succeed and do good: and I have a desire to visit it periodically, in union with the judgment of my friends there.

You will find the discussion with Dalton and Jones scarcely interesting. They are not so eager to print their discussions with me. This with Stephens is not likely to see print. Had it been any body else, there would have been a flaming newspaper to[-]do. now I doubt if it will find notice in the Northern Star. I am certainly in a curious predicament as to pastors in this country at present: every one of them alike shy of me; but I shall work my way out to something eminent among them. Love to Mrs Turton and the Likely Mary Ann and others?Girls -

[[5]] P.S. since I last write, I have made the acquaintance of Mr Acland[?], who figured at Bristol, Hull and last at Stockport. He is now trying Manchester and Salford. He has got into a quarrel with Stephens, which I rather regret. Neither of them are theological reformers but I have been trying to school both and have interested both with my revelation of the Bible Mystery. Both say it is beautiful; but Stephens says let us get the New Poor Law Amendment Act repealed first: and Acland says, let us keep it on: so there or here there are at daggers drawn, and will not use me as a mediator: and I wish to be a mediator between them. Oh! these public men! and oh! for those who are led by the nose through them and who cannot think for themselves.

A deputation has been here with a project of a National Petition and a National Fast for Universal Suffrage: and after that, not getting it, a national disuse of exciseable articles. The old story revived â€” the to nothing story.
[[6]] Alfred wants me to start a weekly pamphlet at his risk. I have offered to do so and to call it The Church.
